text:
Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
If you’re due to cast your vote in the Gateshead constituency on June 8 we’ve got everything you need to know right here. 
Britain will go to the polls to elect a government and prime minister after Theresa May called a snap general election. 
We’ll be covering events on our live blog on election day, but in the meantime we’ve got the information you need before you decide which box to put your cross in. Which parties and candidates standing in Gateshead? 
Labour - Ian Mearns WITH VIDEO Rally and march against possible cuts to vital services, at Gateshead Civic Centre ---- Gateshead MP Ian Mearns 
Born in Newcastle in April 1957. Mr Mearns was educated at St Mary’s RC Primary School, Forest Hall and St Mary’s RC Technical School in Newcastle, before starting work with Northern Gas in 1974. 
Mr Mearns was chair of the campaign for a North East Assembly and was a member of the North East Constitutional Convention Steering Group. 
Formerly member of the North East Assembly, he chaired the Scrutiny and Policy Development Board of NEA for almost three years. 
Vice chair of Gateshead’s Diversity Forum, Mr Mearns has experience of working with community leaders from across the borough. 
Mr Mearns takes a keen interest in news, current affairs and regional politics. He is also a keen sports fan and regularly attend concerts encompassing a broad range of music. 
Conservatives - Lauren Hankinson 
Lauren Hankinson is the Tory candidate for Gateshead. 
Her address is listed as in Westminster, London. 
Lauren says she will be campaigning to get Gateshead, and the UK, the best Brexit deal possible. 
The solicitor says she wants “fairer funding” for schools, to improve services and will work with businesses to take advantage of the Government’s new Industrial Strategy to build “high-skilled economy” in Gateshead. 
Liberal Democrats - Frank Hindle Frank Hindle, Liberal Democrat councillor (Photo: USM - supplied picture) 
Frank has lived in Gateshead most of his life, having moved over the Tyne from Newcastle when was 10. 
He was a councillor for 25 years and led the opposition between 2011 and 2015. A former teacher and lecturer, he left Northumbria University in 2010 to focus on his role as a councillor. 
Mr Hindle opposes a hard Brexit, saying it would hurt the people of Gateshead and leave the NHS, care services and education under-resourced. He also says job prospects and housing in Gateshead need to be improved. 
Green - Andy Redfern 
After standing in the 2010 and 2015 General Elections, Andy Redfern is returning for the Green Party. 
Previously a director for a Team Valley-based fair trade company, he also helped found Ethical Superstore. 
Mr Redfern is a big supporter of sustainable transport and has campaigned for improved links to and from the Team Valley. 
The married father-of-five lives in Lobley Hill, Gateshead. 
He says the Green Party can make a “genuine difference” to the lives of people in Gateshead, and calls for a public transport overhaul. 
UK Independence Party - Mark Bell 
UKIP’s candidate for Gateshead, Mark Bell, comes from Deckham. 
Mr Bell stood in Blaydon in 2015 
ChronicleLive has contacted the local UKIP branch to ask for information about him. What was the result in Gateshead in 2015 
Ian Mearns won 21,549 votes at the last General Election, a 56.8% share. 
UKIP came second, with 17.8%, while the Conservatives won 14.5%. 
The Lib Dems won 6.8% of the vote, with the Green Party taking 4.1%. 
Which parties and MPs have held the seat in the past? 
The seat was reintroduced in 2010 after being abolished in 1950. 
Mr Mearns has held it since 2010. Before that, Labour held it between 1924 and 1931, when the National Liberal Party took it. 
In 1945 Labour won the seat again, but MP Konni Zilliacus switched to Labour Independent group and then Independent Labour in 1949 and 1950. Where do I cast my vote? 
Gateshead’s list of polling stations is here: http://www.gateshead.gov.uk/DocumentLibrary/council/elections/Elections2017/Situation-of-polling-stations-Gateshead.pdf 
Your poll card, which will be sent to your home address, will tell you where to go. Like us on Facebook
